subject: Newbie question - Testing Applets
msgSnippet: Hi guys, The reason I started to learn JUnit and Java in general is that I ve just begun my internship and I m going to write unit tests for an existing
messageBody:
Hi guys,

The reason I started to learn JUnit and Java in general is that I've
just begun my internship and I'm going to write unit tests for an
existing application, developed by "real" programmers :)

The application I'm going to work on first is a Java applet, so I've
focused on finding out how to use JUnit to test them. Having done some
experiments, I've tried to find some sample projects to show me if I
just do it the right way, but unfortunately I haven't found much.

That's why I'd be extremely grateful if someone will just take a look
at what I've written and tell me if I have the right idea of using
JUnit to test applet-based applications and if I'll be able to test
real, functional applets this way in the future.

Thank you,
Anna


//-----------------------------------------------------------
// AppletClass.java - simple applet from "Thinking in Java"
//-----------------------------------------------------------
import javax.swing.*;

public class AppletClass extends JApplet {
public void init() {
getContentPane().add(new JLabel("Applet!"));
}
}


//-----------------------------------------------------------
// AppletClassTest.java - what I've written
//-----------------------------------------------------------

import javax.swing.JApplet;
import junit.framework.JUnit4TestAdapter;
// (and so on...)


public class AppletClassTest {
JApplet applet;
JFrame frame;

@Before public void before(){
applet = new AppletClass();

frame = new JFrame("AppletClass!");
// To close the application:
frame.setDefaultCloseOperation(JFrame.EXIT_ON_CLOSE);
frame.getContentPane().add(applet);
frame.setSize(100,50);

applet.init();
applet.start();

}

@After public void after(){
applet.stop();
applet.destroy();
}

@Test public void appletNotNull(){
Assert.assertNotNull("Hey, the applet reference is null!", applet);
}

@Test public void frameContentPaneIncludesApplet(){
Component[] tbl = frame.getContentPane().getComponents();
boolean result = false;

//search for the applet
for (int i=0; i<tbl.length; i++)
if ( tbl[i].equals(applet) ) {
result=true;
break;
}
Assert.assertEquals(true, result);
}

@Test public void appletComponentsCountOK(){
Assert.assertEquals(1,applet.getContentPane().getComponentCount());
}

public static junit.framework.Test suite() {

return new JUnit4TestAdapter(AppletClassTest.class);
}
}
